headline: Hong Kong Protesters Square Off With Police
summary: Violence between protesters and police spread across five districts late Saturday, with several police stations besieged and hundreds of residents pouring on to the streets to drive riot police from their neighborhood.

headline: Honduran President Is Accused of Drug Conspiracy
summary: U.S. prosecutors accused Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernández of conspiring with his brother and other top politicians to protect drug traffickers.

headline: ‘Moulin Rouge!’ Broadway Tickets Go for Aristocrat Prices
summary: Broadway has a new wallet-busting smash: “Moulin Rouge! The Musical” is charging nearly $500 for premium seats, putting it second only to “Hamilton” among Broadway productions.

headline: White House Weighs September Rollout of Health Plan
summary: The Trump administration is considering releasing its long-promised health-care plan in September as part of a campaign strategy to offer an alternative to plans of Democratic candidates.

headline: Capital One Hack Puts Low-Profile CEO in Spotlight
summary: Capital One is under scrutiny after a hacker exposed the personal information of some 106 million people, raising questions about the technology CEO Richard Fairbank has promoted.

headline: States Battle Treasury Over Billions in Unclaimed Savings Bonds
summary: States and the U.S. Treasury are in a tug of war over what to do with $25 billion in matured, unclaimed U.S. savings bonds, many of which date to WWII.

headline: Berkshire Posts Rising Profit and Cash Pile
summary: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway said second-quarter earnings rose due to unrealized investment gains, while the company’s cash pile grew to a record $122 billion.

headline: New York City to Start Cleanup of Public Cemetery
summary: Next month, New York City will begin cleaning up unearthed human remains and restoring the damaged sea wall along the shoreline of Hart Island, which is one of the largest public cemeteries in the country.

headline: Scientists Search for Best Way to Restore Oysters in Chesapeake Bay
summary: The number of oysters in the Chesapeake Bay has declined by half over the past 10 years, prompting scientists to look for new ways to restore the population.

headline: M.B.A. Students Have Billions in Federal Loans, Data Show
summary: Department of Education figures show that roughly 92,800 people who took out federal student loans and graduated with a master’s degree in business administration in 2016 and 2017 together had about $3.7 billion in such loans.

headline: ‘Pierre Cardin: Future Fashion’ Review: A Cosmic Couture Visionary
summary: A Brooklyn Museum exhibition highlights the career of the French designer, now 97, who shook the fashion world with his passion for ready-to-wear clothing and outré sci-fi aesthetics.

headline: Why Trump Has Deported Fewer Immigrants Than Obama
summary: President Trump is struggling to crank up his promised deportations in part because of legal challenges to President Obama’s aggressive efforts and the scrapping of a program that allowed jailed unauthorized immigrants to be quickly identified.

headline: Justice Department Probes Bubble Wrap Maker’s Auditor Selection Process
summary: Sealed Air Corp. said in a regulatory filing Friday it received a grand jury subpoena seeking information related to the firing of its finance chief and the selection process of its independent audit firm beginning in fiscal year 2015.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: U.S. Levies New Sanctions Against Russia for U.K. Spy Poisoning
summary: The Trump administration is set to impose new sanctions on Russia for using a banned chemical weapon in an attempted assassination of a former double agent on British soil last year, a senior administration official said.

headline: When Battlefield Surveillance Comes to Your Town
summary: All-seeing 24/7 video surveillance technology, first developed for use in war, is now affordable enough to be used domestically to fight crime and terrorism. Some lawmakers are wary.

headline: Everyone Hates Customer Service. This Is Why.
summary: Technology lets companies see how badly they can treat consumers, right up until the moment they bolt. They track how long people will wait, how many ads they will tolerate and their tone of voice. “There is more data available on just how disgruntled someone can be.”

headline: The Ecstatic Chaos of Woodstock
summary: Fifty years later, the music festival remains a symbol of the 1960s’ hope and squalor.
